reviewText:
Early Access Review

----------------
About the gameplay
----------------

It feels like someone's trying to make another version of Total Annihilation, but couldn't program a second resource.

Skirmishes are absolutely insane. There's no wait period, no breathing room, no chance for you to think for a moment about your next step.
It's hurry and teleport in" before someone steals your rez node and then you gotta turn around 'cause you already have baddies gunning at your dropship.

If you somehow survived the first wave AND managed to snag at least one node
date: then you have very little time to build up your strength before the meteorites show.\nThey show every 800 resources. Global. Meaning that if you didn't get one of the first two nodes
recommended: you're screwed with only your servo and the starter turret.\n\nIf you manage to get a roving force and destroy one of the two meteors (they drop them in pairs
voteText: then another one will take its place.\n\nI can't recall of any other strategy game that does this. Dawn of War
votesHelpful: Age of Empires... Even the freaking MOBAs give you a little breather between waves.\n\nThis reminds me of a map I once made for Blood. Since I made it
votesTotal: I knew the order and where every secret was located at
votesFunny: and assumed everyone would be able to figure it out.\nNot the case. I received evey complaint about difficulty and got a bad score because I realized you could glitch the dogs at the first room by going prone under them
commentsCount:
but not everyone else did.


----------------
About the AI
----------------

Jesus ♥♥♥♥ing Christ.

Why on Earth would you allow allies to build within your influence if THERE IS NO RESOURCE SHARING!?

SO. MANY. ♥♥♥♥ING. TIMES. I have had the AI claim all the resource spots when THEY'RE NOT EVEN THERE!

I've only been able to play this with AI
column16: since I haven't been able to get paired with someone online
column17: but I'm absolutely certain you can get stuck with a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ teammate that will steal every resource node from under you
column19:
telling yourself "Why did I download this?"

I know it's an early access game. I don't care. It's currently not worth the buy.

----------------
About the customization
----------------

You'd think that for a game that boasts about customization
column20: they'd have at least several different parts set up. So far
column21:
I've only seen:
-first weapon
-sword
-pistol
-rifle
-shoulder rocket (single)
-shoulder grenade launcher

All bodyparts are exactly the same
column22: with slight variations in color.\n\nOh yeah. There as a shield unit in there
column23:
but it was so weak that It was essentially the same as going naked.

----------------
Final thoughts
----------------

Right now it's not worth the buy. Maybe check again in a few months.

Don't buy early access stuff this early! If they sell every copy during early access
column24: they won't have any reason to finish the game!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So, what can I say about this game.

If you want to read a whole review, then look no further. If you're one of THOSE guys, that just want to know if the game is good.....well...look no further either.
Let's start with the short one.

Game good. You play. You smile. You happy. The End.

And now for those of you who want to know MY thoughts and experiences with the game. Also know, I go for a full blown out review, as such is my...way of the ninja? Cause I have quite a bit I really want to get out. So bare with me. Or not.


First a little story about me.
As a young little ninja child Age of Empires were pretty much my one favorite game. Even to this day it pretty much is. So you can probably understand that, when I read, and I quote, key create talent behind the beloved Age of Empires seriers"
date: I got pretty excited in my...head. So
voteText: but who cares

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off I know allot of people say ohh this is like total annillation or supreme commander - no its not

the only 2 things these games have in common is mechas and RTS to compare them to each other does not do either justice
why? time - time is a big factor in these games a single match of Total annillation or supreme commander could take hours where as this game is made to take 10-15mins per match in a more get in and get shooting mentality - if your lead unit dies the timer resets on it and you respawn it free of charge giving you a range of options as long as you protect your command ship

so we now what its not - so what is it? I'd say this game is closer to metal fatigue or air mech then what most compare this game to - its fast in your face no time to debate or pause and make strategy - get in shoot use your mechs special attacks and hope you hold long enough to snag some resources and make some generic units to back up your servos

the co op hold your own map reminds me more of Dawn of war 2 Last Stand as you get waves of enemies while trying to collect resources and build up - the limited resource types helps keep your mind on fighting over micromanagement is a bonus since attempting to sweep away enemies with limited resources can be tough

So buy this game if you are looking for
a fast paced RTS with RPG style
quick in your face matches
a interesting choice of mecha options- arm them with pistols swords grenade launchers brass nuckles rifles and differnt armors and pilots
the pvp is fun quick shoot em up style rts

Don't buy it if your looking for
a new supreme commander - or total annilation - these are not the same please stop comparing them I love total annilation far to much for people to keep bashing every game in its name - they are not the same let the game rest in peace
a long in depth campain or story line - these are pretty much just not in the game only 2 campains to get you started I already beat them in first 2 hours of play on all difficultys
a no bugs perfect in all ways game - its early access it has bugs it has some wierdness and balancing needs major work still - does that make it less fun? for some yes so hit follow or wishlist it till you think its worth the cash

so after 2 hours would I buy it again? yes - 7/10 solid early access with tons of potentiol (and I'm talking real diamond in the rough not great "personality" )

also to anyone who attempts to troll me or leave some grammar nazi response I will delete you - if you have a legit response or complaint about my post I'm all for responding so please ask away

but folks remember - I'm a gamer not a Grammar professor so please please keep that kinda rage for facebook maybe youtube but don't leave it on my door step I won't deal with it

reviewText:
Early Access Review

edit: Update for people reading this in early 2016 and considering purchase. Updates to the beta are very slow now. If you are only preordering I can still recommend the game, if the planned price increase happens 20 bux is a deep discount. But, it is not worth buying just to play the beta. Cautious types may want to wait and see despite the prospect of a good price.

This game is still in beta, but it is in very safe hands. The developers are all industry veterans with a record of shipping good games. Patches are coming regularly about 2 weeks apart with many changes and added content each update.

If I had to compare it to anything it would be Warcraft III. You have 3 heroes and a base, units and creeps on the map, the objective is blow up the other guy's base. There is also a coop mode offering a variety of challenges against both creeps and dug in AI forces.

2 major things separate it from WC3, heroes do not gather XP from creeps, they gather resources which can be spent on anything. The heroes go up in rank with your base, which is done by buying resources. The other is the hero units are customized giant robots made out of parts you get out of loot crates, bought between matches with ingame currency.

This is where the game gets really interesting, parts can give your robots stat boosts and abilities. There are many types of items with more on the way. The way your hero team will play depends on these parts. They give you a lot of free parts at the start to let you try this out.

There are no free to play elements, or additional monetization beyond the box price. It features profile levels, though. Thankfully, this level has a cap and it is reasonable to reach, and being a beta not many people are bothering to get to max level. Grinding is not a requirement to enjoy the beta. Players are a little scarce right now, this is best enjoyed in multiplayer so I recommend having a friend to play it with. The game only has 2 player modes so far though. The solo version of coop can be fun but single player isn't quite as fleshed out as multiplayer.

Being a beta there are times where things change a lot between updates and items are changed, removed, or your profile completely reset. If you want a complete game, wait a while. If you don't mind beta games Jump In. You can see quite a lot of the content playing multiplayer casually.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys customization and the RTS play style. There are bugs to deal with but it is early in game development so keep that in mind. I would like to see more content for the Mechs and possibly more Drones (Mini brawling drones, for front line fighting?). The game is similar to a MOBA/RTS play style. The game reminds me a lot of Warcraft 3 when Blizzard introduced heros into the RTS game play. There is great potential for this game but that doesnt mean it will amount to greatness. If the developers continue taking feed back from the community to heart to expand on the foundation they have laid, this will be a great game to pick up for 20 bucks.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Developers disappeared from the face of the Earth for six months, only to reappear and announce that Stardock will no longer be publishing the game and they're thinking about what to do next. They even asked players for advice on what to do! This doesn't instil much confidence. I applied for a refund, but no luck (have had the game for more than two weeks).

In any case, my advice is not to buy this game until it has been properly released and you've had the chance to read some reviews about the game. Right now, it doesn't seem like there's going to be much progress and there's no telling at this point what the game will eventually look like. Avoid.

Update 3 June 2016: a new patch is incoming. Notice: incoming. It's not released, but in development. And what are they focusing on? Some balance changes, making things faster, and squashing a few bugs. The bottom line: they did nothing with Servo for more than half a year and now they've basically restarted development with this new patch that will change the game in small ways only. Too little, too late: continue to avoid this for now.

I cant really tell you if this game is good or not because i have played this game for almost no amount of time. The reason being is because this game is not toaster friendly as of currently.

I bought this game thinking it would be great fun, and still do! The only problem is that I have a above average toaster. I tried to play this game and my average FPS was about 2-3. Once i turned down the setting to the third lowest possibility (to the point where this size text was made up of 4-7 pixels) the fps jumped up... to around 5-6 FPS.

Basically im trying to say if you have a good computer get this game. Otherwise, you should probably save your money until later because this issue may be due to it being very early in the making.

Toasters beware of the great and mighty servo!

P.S. From what i have seen of it outside of the actual gameplay the game is awesome.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well I have to admit I was very eager to get this game: Giant fighting mech suits, Exp system, loot and a whole load of other pluses? I couldn't stay away.

The overall impression is that this game has potential to be a huge amount of fun, even for an Alpha stage game I was actually impressed with several of the mechanics involved.

The building system for the RTS side of it is simple to pick up and after a few games you will, be putting your roots down quickly and getting on with the fun part of smashing the enemy to bits.

As for the customisation of your mechs? Well yet again has great potential. Whether you're a gunslinger, boxer or sniper there are loadouts for you. There is as yet no options to customise colour so your look is completely down to what gear you have.

The basic weapons are complemented by extra things like shields and rockect pacs so the potential for a wide range of fighting styles is in the pipeline and mix that in with each poilet's own powers I feel I will be dreaming up new builds for weeks at least.

A key refreshing element is the servo team idea itself, you with every tech level you get an additional servo to use in game from the stock of already unlocked pilots. By early mid game you can have a whole squad of stompy mechs to deal damage with.

So the rougher points:

Obviously the game isn't finished, so while it's good fun to play a few times right now you will quickly chew through the early access content. Though even this isn't too bad as even though you can't access all the cool things now they are there, especially in with the A.I controlled servos who are armed with some of the shinier things you will be able to get just to make you drool and feel good about yourself as you pound their over geared mechs to scrap ^_^

On the subject of the A.I, sadly they will not tax you terribly right now, with only basic commands and some almost hilariously stupid actions (Ignoring your entire army/base defences to chase one little drone round and around or just sitting at their own base scratching their heads as you claim the whole map. But as I said before early days.

There is some balancing issues to be resolved, but yet again that is nothing new to a work in progress game. Some one of the two co-op levels is simply impossible with an A.I ally to complete while the other is hardly taxing at all. Unless you raise it the next difficulty and watch your A.I ally dance in circles.

The only major gripes I have is the loot drops and lack of other players right now. It is almost sole destroying to earn the in game currency, playing for hours for what feels like terrible small gains. From what I have seen it takes at least four games to earn a reasonable quality loot crate which turns out to be another gun you don't need.

This is offset somewhat by the 'daily quests' where you have to achieve certain goals like building ten base turrets ect, but in my experience it's not enough.

Yes you've crushed your foe in an epic battle, ground his servos to scrap and blasted his base to atoms. You finally catch your breath and find what feels like a couple of loose coat buttons and can of knock off soft drink for your troubles.

The devs has stated that the early release focuses on multiplayer right now, which is all fine and dandy except the teaming up engine seems to be lacking at the moment. I was lucky to find a fellow player to duke it out with (In co-op or PVP) having only had about five games with other people since I got the game a few days ago, less than one in ten searches resulting in a match.

So to conclude my review I would say this game will be awesome if they keep up the good work. As for buying it right this second? Not so sure. You will have a few hours fun testing out the basic format and gaming system. If you have a dedicated friend to play it with, to strive and overcome the co-op missions or to beat the snot out of in PVP then the fun will last longer.

I would see it as a long term investment, the more people who support the game now will hopefully encourage the devs and we will see more cool content sooner. The big promise that is given is this game will not be a 'pay to win', everything will be included in the one time payment of the game.

Over all I'd give this a thumbs up, with hope that it lives up to expectations. Buy investing in the game you make it more likely that a real gem will be at the end of the tunnel. If you're not up for that risk then it may be worth waiting to see where it goes.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For those of you that remember Metal fatigue, this game scratches that itch! Although not as in-field dynamic as metal fatigue, such as being able to swap parts from fallen foes in the middle of battle. It does however let you customize your pilot, head, torso, legs and a weapon on each hand and each shoulder. Choice of weapons is pretty broad, which is nice.

my only complaint? no WASD map move. It's either screen bump or using the arrow keys like it's 1999.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nServo is a very interesting twist on the giant machine combat of Planetary Annihilation in that you can tune the robot to your playstyle by selecting different pilots and swapping out main and special weapons without sacrificing anything. It's very easy to slip into and the skills you can learn in the tutorial can still aid you online. If you wish to dip your toes into the RTS genre, I suggest you check this one out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alpha/EA first impressions: This is sort of the RTS version of what Torchlight is to RPG/Diablo-esque games. It's arcadey and a little cartoony but it's fun and even the alpha/EA version runs well and has a variety of game modes even if certain things are placeholder or a little sparse still. You can have up to 3 Servos in battle along with 15-20 or so drones in a typical skirmish. There are several different types of drones, eco and armoury upgrades, turrets, unit producing factories, healing beacons, some neutral roaming monsters and different economy nodes around the map to capture. There's a variety of gear and parts you can earn and swap around on your Servos between games to go for certain playstyles. It will have a campaign/SP side on release and has MP and Co-Op already. I'd like to see it get a bit more depth and character as it develops. It is a little too generic/cartoony for my tastes aesthetically right now but, again, it's an alpha and there's a lot more to be added so I'm curious where they will take it.
Update: Changing my review to a thumbs down. One of my few Early Access regrets. It's been many months since my initial review and there's been zero communication from the devs on what's happening with the game. There was a single small update in the past 6 months. The game stopped working on my new W10 PC and support was not able to find a reason or solution. I've completely lost interest in the game and it seems the devs have as well...

I would love to be able to limit how many servos players can have in skirmish mode, for example (3 is too many imo). But otherwise its pretty fun.
